Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the extent to which the Colorado caucus system is "rigged" by implying that there was no voting at all, when in fact people did vote at every level of the delegate selection process.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to prove that the Colorado caucus system is truly "rigged" and deprived people of their vote.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the changes made to the caucus rules were specifically aimed at disenfranchising Trump, without providing evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for Trump's struggles in state caucuses, such as his campaign's lack of a strong ground game and unfamiliarity with the complex caucus process.
Understate: The claim may understate the complexities and nuances of the Colorado caucus system by simply labeling it as "rigged" without fully exploring the intricacies of the process.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that people did vote at every level of the delegate selection process in the Colorado caucus system.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing sufficient evidence or addressing counterarguments.
